turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I'm finally tackling this bathroom remodel. I'm starting with the tiling and I'm already confused. I bought these 12x24 inch porcelain tiles, but I'm not sure what size trowel notch I need to use. Any advice?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: For 12x24 inch porcelain tiles, a 1/4-inch by 3/8-inch square-notch trowel is generally recommended. Make sure to apply the thin-set mortar evenly and press the tiles firmly into place with a slight twisting motion.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, great! 1/4 x 3/8 it is. But I've also heard that back buttering the tiles is really important with larger format tiles. Is that absolutely necessary, or can I get away without it?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Back buttering is highly recommended for tiles of that size, especially porcelain. It ensures full mortar coverage and prevents voids, which can lead to cracking and other issues down the line. While you *could* skip it, the long-term consequences might be more trouble than it's worth.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Ugh, fine. I'll do it. Now, for the really tricky question. I'm planning on installing a linear shower drain. What's the best way to ensure a proper slope towards the drain with these large tiles? This is stressing me out!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That can be a bit challenging! The ideal method is to use a pre-sloped shower pan or a mortar bed that is sloped during installation. You'll want to aim for a slope of about 1/4 inch per foot towards the linear drain. Using a level and straight edge is crucial for accuracy. There are also numerous videos on YouTube that show how to do this. Would you like some links to some videos?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Links would be fantastic! I've watched a few, but more references are always helpful. Thanks!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, here are a few YouTube links that should help with installing a linear shower drain. [Link 1 - Fictional], [Link 2 - Fictional], [Link 3 - Fictional]. Remember to always check your local building codes before undertaking any major renovations.
